%text If a random variable $(X)$ can have \underline\text{only} values from the set $\lbrace x_1, x_2, \ldots x_n\rbrace$, then it's \underline\text{probability distribution is a table} that lists the values and the probabilties of getting those values - as shown below % \begin{align} \begin{tabular}{NNNNN}
\hline X & x_1 & x_2 & \ldots & x_n \\ \hline P(X=x_i) & p_1 &p_2& \ldots & p_n \\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{align} %text As $X$ can only be one of $x_1, x_2 \ldots x_n $, hence it should come as no surprise that \[ \qquad\qquad \sum_{k=1}^n p_k = 1 \]%
